TEXT:
Patient seen an examined with MICU team.  I agree with their assessment
   and plan of care.
   Chief Complaint:  Hypoxemia x 2 days
   HPI:
   Briefly 80 F with CAD, CHF, CVA, gastroparesis, Stage IV sarcoidosis,
   and poorly controlled COPD.  She has a 2 year history of multiple
   abdominal surgeries: initially a sigmoid resection for large bowel
   obstruction c/b anastomotic leak and multiple episodes of
   intra-abdominal abscesses requiring surgical correction and revision,
   diverticulitis with colovesicular fistula in [**2169**] that required partial
   colonic resection and an ileostomy. In [**2170-12-4**], she had the ileostomy
   reversed and since then, she has had worsening of her diarrhea.
   Since [**Month (only) **], she has been admitted to OSH 5 times for long hospital stays
   with extensive work up that has been negative so far. Most recently,
   she was admitted to OSH [**3-27**] where workup again has been negative. She
   has been getting IVF; lasix held. The family requested a transfer to
   [**Hospital1 19**] this for a 2nd opinion at a [**Hospital 7454**] care center for her GI
   symptoms.  Two hours prior to transfer she developed gradually
   worsening dyspnea and an oxygen requirement.
   She was transferred to [**Hospital1 19**] on supplemental oxygen. On arrival to the
   floor, she required 6LNC and was saturating 88%. ABG showed paO2 of 54.
   CXR was consistent with significant pulm edema. 40 mg IV lasix was
   given with 200cc UOP. Her saturation improved on hi flow venti mask
   saturating 95%.
   A CVL was placed but coiled into the SC.
   Because of her hypoxia from CHF and likely PNA (leukocytosis, low grade
   fever, sputum, cough), she was transferred to the MICU for further
   care.
   24 Hour Events:
   Vanco and aztreonam started.  CXR shows patchy opaicities- about the
   same as [**4-11**].
   Witnessed aspiration event during AM med administration.
   In the MICU she received lasix 60 IV with 500 cc u/o.
   She did not tolerate BIPAP
   After diuresis her oxygen requirement declined to 60% but while on
   rounds she became solmnolent and then unresponsive and hypoxemic
   shortly after removal of her right IJ CVL that was malpositioned.  Her
   lung exam was notable for bilateral breath sounds, diffuse expiratory
   wheeze.
   She was then emergently intubated.  Post intubation ABG notable for
   PO2=170 on 100% FIO2.  Solumedrol 125 IV given x 1 but not continued
   after vent mechanics revealed Ppeak=27, Pplat=25
   Placed on LTV ventilatory strategy.
   OGT placed with copious feculent material aspirated (airway clear on
   intubation per anesthesia).
   Allergies:
   Latex Gloves (Miscell) (Gloves
   Latex)

The patient is an 80-year-old female with a history of CAD, CHF, CVA, gastroparesis, stage IV sarcoidosis, and poorly controlled COPD. She has undergone multiple abdominal surgeries, including sigmoid resection for large bowel obstruction, multiple episodes of intra-abdominal abscesses, diverticulitis with colovesicular fistula, and partial colonic resection with ileostomy. She also had an ileostomy reversal and has been experiencing worsening diarrhea. The patient has been admitted to OSH five times for long hospital stays with extensive workups that have been negative so far. Most recently, she was admitted to OSH and received IV fluids and lasix, but her family requested a transfer to Hospital1-19 for a second opinion on her GI symptoms. Two hours prior to the transfer, she developed gradually worsening dyspnea and required supplemental oxygen.

On arrival at Hospital1-19, the patient required 6LNC and had a saturation of 88%. ABG showed a paO2 of 54, and a chest X-ray showed significant pulmonary edema. She was given 40 mg IV lasix and her saturation improved to 95% on a high-flow venti mask. A central venous line (CVL) was placed but coiled into the subclavian vein. Summary:
The patient is a critically ill 80-year-old female with a complex medical history including coronary artery disease (CAD), congestive heart failure (CHF), cerebrovascular accident (CVA), gastroparesis, stage IV sarcoidosis, and poorly controlled chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). She has had multiple abdominal surgeries, including sigmoid resection for large bowel obstruction with anastomotic leak, multiple episodes of intra-abdominal abscesses requiring surgical correction, diverticulitis with colovesicular fistula, and partial colonic resection with ileostomy. She also had ileostomy reversal and worsening diarrhea since then.

The patient has been admitted to the hospital multiple times for long hospital stays with extensive workups that have been negative so far. Most recently, she was admitted for worsening dyspnea and oxygen requirement. She was transferred to another hospital for a second opinion regarding her gastrointestinal symptoms. Upon arrival at the new hospital, she required supplemental oxygen and her ABG showed a paO2 of 54 with significant pulmonary edema on chest X-ray. She was given 40 mg IV lasix with 200cc UOP, and her saturation improved on high-flow venti mask, saturating 95%.

TEXT:
Chief Complaint:
   HPI:
   80 F with CAD, CHF, CVA, ILD, COPD and multiple abdominal surgeries
   tranfer from OSH for 2nd opinion of diarrhea. She had diverticulitis
   with colovesicular fistula in [**2169**] that required partial colonic
   resection and an ileostomy. In [**2170-12-4**], she had the ileostomy reversed
   and since then, she has had worsening of her diarrhea. In fact, since
   [**Month (only) **], she has been admitted to OSH 5 times for long hospital stays with
   extensive work up that has been negative so far. Most recently, she was
   admitted to OSH [**3-27**] where workup again has been negative. She has been
   getting IVF; lasix held. The family requested a transfer to [**Hospital1 19**] this
   morning for a 2nd opinion at a [**Hospital 7454**] care center. Of note this
   morning, she had flash pulm edema and was given 40mg IV lasix with
   [**2162**]+cc urine output.
   .
   She was transferred to [**Hospital1 19**] on supplemental oxygen. On arrival to the
   floor, she required 6LNC and was saturating 88%. ABG showed paO2 of 54.
   CXR was consistent with significant pulm edema. 40 mg IV lasix was
   given with 200cc UOP. Her saturation improved on hi flow venti mask
   saturating 95%. Of note, her central line is not at the proper place in
   the Xray. Because of her hypoxia from CHF and likely PNA (leukocytosis,
   low grade fever, sputum, cough), she was transferred to the MICU for
   further care.
   .
   At the OSH, she was started on sucrulfate for gastritis, reglan for
   mild gastroparesis and nortyptilline. She was also kept on immodium
   standing at 4mg [**Hospital1 7**] and psyllium. Her surgeons felt that she had a
   "short colon". She underwent colonscopy and EGD w/o diagnosis.
   24 Hour Events:
   Got Lasix  60 iv total overnight with appx 500cc.
   BIPAP started [**4-10**] but patient did not tolerate.  Now on 60% Hi-flow.
   Right IJ malpositioned.
   Vanco and aztreonam started.  CXR shows patchy opaicities- about the
   same as [**4-11**].
   Witnessed aspiration event during AM med administration.

   Assessment and Plan
   In Summary, patient is 80 yo female with ILD, COPD and now found with
   severe hypoxemia in the setting of diffuse evidence of pulmonary
   infiltrates consistent with pulmonary edema.  She has had significant
   volume load although patient did have severe acute decompensation over
   past hours
this may be hydrostatic edema which would be supported by
   small bilateral effusions but patient with warm extremities and unclear
   underlying cardiac function.  She has had Lasix with minimal
   improvement.  Alternative sources are certainly aspiration with diffuse
   pneumonitis.  In addition
GI or alternative source for sepsis is
   certainly possible with evolution of diffuse Acute Lung Injury.
   Finally, viral pneumonia or atypical bacterial pneumonia is possible.
   PULM: Oxygen, defer on imaging.  IF she stabilizes obtain chest CT.
   Nebs for COPD.  Likely is aspirating.
   CV: hemodynamically stable. TBB even.  Obtain TTE.  Pull malpositioned
   CVL.
   GI: NPO.  Place NGT.  GI consult.
   ID: Vanco./aztreonam empricially.  F/U blood, urine, stool, and
   legionella.
   RENAL: Replete K
   PPX: Heparin SC.
   DISPO: FULL CODE.
   ACCESS: pull CVL and try for second PIV.  IF needed she will get a new
   line.
   Respiratory Failure
Clearly hypoxemic
   -Will continue with supplemental oxygen
   -Vanco/Aztreonam to continue
   -Lasix given and look for response over time
   -Will check Legionella
   -ACE-I for afterload reduction
   -Intubation discussed and may well be required and patient is amenable
   if required

Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is an 80-year-old female with a history of CAD, CHF, CVA, ILD, COPD, and multiple abdominal surgeries. She was admitted to the ICU for a second opinion regarding diarrhea, which was initially diagnosed as diverticulitis with a colovesicular fistula. The patient underwent partial colonic resection and ileostomy, followed by ileostomy reversal. Since then, she has experienced worsening diarrhea and has been admitted multiple times for extensive workups that have been negative. Most recently, she was admitted with flash pulmonary edema and received IV Lasix. She required supplemental oxygen upon transfer to the floor and subsequently to the MICU due to hypoxia from CHF and likely pneumonia. The patient has a central line malpositioned on X-ray. She is currently on sucralfate for gastritis, reglan for gastroparesis, and nortriptyline. She is also on imodium, psyllium, and other medications as per her surgeons' recommendation. The patient's allergies include latex, aspirin, colchicine, antihistamines, quinolones, vasodilators, loratadine, theophylline, opioids, cortisone, iodine, and levaquin. Her last dose of antibiotics was vancomycin on 04/12/2017 at 01:10 AM, but aztreonam has been ordered

Summary:
The patient is an 80-year-old female with a history of interstitial lung disease (ILD) and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). She was found with severe hypoxemia and diffuse pulmonary infiltrates consistent with pulmonary edema. The patient has had significant volume overload and experienced severe acute decompensation over the past few hours. There are a few potential medical complications that can arise in this case:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient is clearly hypoxemic, and respiratory failure is already present. The plan is to continue with supplemental oxygen, monitor for improvement, and consider intubation if necessary.

2. Sepsis: The patient may have an alternative source of sepsis, possibly from the gastrointestinal tract or aspiration. This could lead to the development of septic shock and multiorgan dysfunction.

3. Acute lung injury (ALI) or acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS): Given the evolution of diffuse pulmonary infiltrates and the presence of hypoxemia, the patient is at risk for developing ALI/ARDS.

4. Cardiac dysfunction: The patient has warm extremities, but her underlying cardiac function is unclear. Cardiac dysfunction could contribute to the pulmonary edema and may require further investigation and management.

5. Legionella pneumonia: Legionella infection is a possibility and should be ruled out with appropriate testing.

6. Atypical bacterial pneumonia: Another possible cause of the pulmonary infiltrates is atypical bacterial pneumonia.

It is important to closely monitor the

Chief Complaint:
   HPI:
   80 F with CAD, CHF, CVA, ILD, COPD and multiple abdominal surgeries
   tranfer from OSH for 2nd opinion of diarrhea. She had diverticulitis
   with colovesicular fistula in [**2169**] that required partial colonic
   resection and an ileostomy. In [**2170-12-4**], she had the ileostomy reversed
   and since then, she has had worsening of her diarrhea. In fact, since
   [**Month (only) **], she has been admitted to OSH 5 times for long hospital stays with
   extensive work up that has been negative so far. Most recently, she was
   admitted to OSH [**3-27**] where workup again has been negative. She has been
   getting IVF; lasix held. The family requested a transfer to [**Hospital1 19**] this
   morning for a 2nd opinion at a [**Hospital 7454**] care center. Of note this
   morning, she had flash pulm edema and was given 40mg IV lasix with
   [**2162**]+cc urine output.
   .
   She was transferred to [**Hospital1 19**] on supplemental oxygen. On arrival to the
   floor, she required 6LNC and was saturating 88%. ABG showed paO2 of 54.
   CXR was consistent with significant pulm edema. 40 mg IV lasix was
   given with 200cc UOP. Her saturation improved on hi flow venti mask
   saturating 95%. Of note, her central line is not at the proper place in
   the Xray. Because of her hypoxia from CHF and likely PNA (leukocytosis,
   low grade fever, sputum, cough), she was transferred to the MICU for
   further care.
   .
   At the OSH, she was started on sucrulfate for gastritis, reglan for
   mild gastroparesis and nortyptilline. She was also kept on immodium
   standing at 4mg [**Hospital1 7**] and psyllium. Her surgeons felt that she had a
   "short colon". She underwent colonscopy and EGD w/o diagnosis.

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is an 80-year-old female with a history of CAD, CHF, CVA, ILD, COPD, and multiple abdominal surgeries. She was admitted to the ICU due to worsening diarrhea and flash pulmonary edema. The patient has undergone extensive workups that have been negative. She requires supplemental oxygen and has been on non-invasive ventilation since April 11th. A multi-lumen line was inserted on April 12th. The patient's allergies include latex, aspirin, colchicine, antihistamines, quinolones, vasodilators, loratadine, theophylline, opioids, cortisone, iodine, and levaquin.

Assessment and Plan:
The patient is currently experiencing severe hypoxemia with diffuse evidence of pulmonary infiltrates consistent with pulmonary edema. She has had significant volume overload and acute decompensation. The possible causes of her condition include hydrostatic edema, aspiration with diffuse pneumonitis, gastrointestinal or alternative source for sepsis, viral pneumonia, or atypical bacterial pneumonia. The patient is being managed with supplemental oxygen, Lasix, vancomycin/aztreonam, and consideration for intubation if necessary. An ACE inhibitor may be given for afterload reduction, and Legionella testing will be conducted.

Summary:
The patient is a 62-year-old male who presented with shortness of breath and was found to have bilateral infiltrates on chest X-ray, indicating possible pneumonia. The patient was started on non-invasive ventilation and later intubated due to worsening respiratory status. The patient also has a history of hypertension and diabetes.

The patient's current vital signs show a temperature of 37.1C, heart rate of 87 bpm, blood pressure of 137/46 mmHg, respiratory rate of 29 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 93% on high-flow nasal cannula. The patient is in sinus rhythm.

The patient has received several medications including lorazepam, vancomycin, and lasix. The patient's fluid balance shows a total input of 567 mL and output of 100 mL over the past 24 hours.

The patient's arterial blood gas analysis shows a pH of 7.48, PaCO2 of 45 mmHg, PaO2 of 92, and HCO3- of 30 mEq/L. The patient's oxygen delivery device is set to high-flow nasal cannula, ventilator mode is standby, tidal volume is set at 450 mL, peak inspiratory pressure is 5 cmH2O, respiratory rate is set at 9 breaths per minute, positive end-expiratory pressure is 8 cmH2O, fractional inspired oxygen is 60%, and plateau pressure is 0

   Assessment and Plan
 HYPOXEMIA
 DELIRIUM / CONFUSION
   80 F with CAD, CHF, CVA, ILD, COPD and multiple abdominal surgeries
   tranfer from OSH for 2nd opinion of diarrhea who is now admitted to
   MICU for hypoxia.
   .
   #  Hypoxia: PaO2 54 on NC and pt in distress. Tecnichally she meets
   criteria for ARDS> CXR with central patchy infiltrates that could
   represent pulmonary edema vs underlying ILD. Patient has hx ILD but is
   not on home O2. There is no record of CXR on admission to OSH. The
   hypoxia and respiratory distress appear to be an acute change as of
   today. In addition, she is noted to have mild bibasilar crackles on
   exam on admission to [**Hospital3 4015**] but now has diffuse crackles all
   the way up the lung. BNP from OSH is slightly elevated. Taken together
   this suggests that she has acute pulmonary edema. However, idffuse
   infiltrates can also aoccur with ARDS, viral PNA or atypical PNA;
   aspiration is also possible. She does have an elevated WBC and the
   edema may be hiding infiltrates. She has no risk factors for ARDS - no
   sepsis, no pacreatitis, no transfusion. It is unlikely that she would
   have developed viral PNA while at OSH.  We have no prior echo  but pt
   states she has had problems with fluid in her lungs before. EKG is
   notable for IVCD, non-specific Twave changes and small ST depressions
   in V5/V6. She denies CP but could still have had an MI. She is not
   hypertensive. It is unkown if she had afib RVR at OSh but appers to be
   in NSR now at a rate of 92. She has received lasix 40mg IV. Her records
   state that she is allergic to morphine and demerol as well as
   isosorbide.
   - start BiPap
   - ACEi- for afterload given allergy to nitrites
   - diurese 500cc in addition to 400cc already
   - obtain BNP
   - cont Advair and Spiriva
   - cont Amlodipine 5mg daily
   - r/o MI
   - obtain an echo
   - Vanc, Aztreonam for ? HAP
   .
   # Leukocytosis: New as of today. No localizing signs other than
   respiratory failure. Benign abd.
   - stool cx
   - UA and Ux
   - sputum cx
   - given respiratory failure, will give empric abx; Vanc and Aztreonam
   .
   # hx COPD, ? hx ILD: not on home O2
   - cont Advair and Spiriva and Singulair
   .
   # Diarrhea: has had extensive w/u without diagnosis. Leading diagnosis
   is short gut ("short colon") although I beleive short colon does not
   typically cause diarrhea. Infections have been repeated r/o.
   Microscopic colitis is under consideration and biopsies are pending at
   OSH. Likewise labs for VIPoma, carcinoid syndrom and fat malabsorbtion
   are pending. Pancreatic insufficiency should also be considered.
   - cont Metamucil, nortryptyline and immodium
   - repeat C.diff, O/P, cryto/isosporidium
   - obtain stool na and K for stool osms
   - f/u VIP, 5HIAA, fecal fat from OSH
   - obtain records of colon biopsy and CT scans
   - hold lactobacillus as non-formulary
   .
   # Gastritis/ GERD:
   - cont omeprazole 20 [**Hospital1 7**] , sucrulfate
   .
   # Gastroparesis:
   - cont  reglan 10mg QIDAHC
    .
   # CAD: not on ASA? will need to ask pt when off BiPap
   - cont plavix
   - cont simvastatin
   .
   # Hx Afib: in NSR now at HR 90
   - cont diltiazem 240mg [**Hospital1 7**]
   .
   # Hypothyroidism: TSH was 3.71 at OSH ahd Levothyroxine dose appears to
   have been decreased from 200mg to 100mg daily.
   .
   # FEN:  NPO while on BiPap
   .
   # ACCESS: one PIV, need to pull central line,  ordered a PICC
   # CODE: full, confirmed w son and patient

The patient's current condition includes hypoxemia, delirium/confusion, and possible acute pulmonary edema or ARDS. She also has leukocytosis without localizing signs, a history of COPD and ILD, and ongoing diarrhea without a definitive diagnosis. Other medical conditions include gastritis/GERD, gastroparesis, CAD, atrial fibrillation, hypothyroidism, and fenestrated endotracheal tube placement. The patient's vital signs are as follows: temperature 37.1C (98.8F), heart rate 87 bpm (81-94 bpm), blood pressure 137/46 mmHg (123/46-146/61 mmHg), respiratory rate 29 breaths per minute (24-31 breaths per minute), and oxygen saturation 93%. The patient is currently receiving non-invasive ventilation and multi-lumen catheter insertion. The plan includes initiating BiPap, ACE inhibitor therapy, diuresis, obtaining a BNP, continuing Advair and Spiriva, ruling out MI, obtaining an echo, and administering empirical antibiotics. The patient's allergies include latex, aspirin, colchicine, antihistamines (diphenhydramine H

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 80-year-old female with multiple comorbidities including CAD, CHF, CVA, ILD, COPD, and multiple abdominal surgeries. She was admitted to the ICU for hypoxia and respiratory distress. The patient's medical history indicates a transfer from OSH for a second opinion on diarrhea, which is now admitted to the MICU.

The patient's current assessment and plan include the following:

1. Hypoxia: The patient has a PaO2 of 54 on NC and is in distress. She meets criteria for ARDS, and her CXR shows central patchy infiltrates that could represent pulmonary edema or underlying ILD. The hypoxia and respiratory distress appear to be an acute change. The patient also has mild bibasilar crackles on exam on admission but now has diffuse crackles all the way up the lung. An elevated BNP suggests acute pulmonary edema. However, diffuse infiltrates can also occur with ARDS, viral PNA, or atypical PNA; aspiration is also possible. She has an elevated WBC and edema may be hiding infiltrates. She has no risk factors for ARDS - no sepsis, no pancreatitis, no transfusion. It is unlikely that she would have developed viral PNA while at OSH. The patient's EKG shows IVCD, non-specific T-wave changes, and small ST depressions in V5/V

The patient is an 80-year-old female with a history of CAD, CHF, CVA, ILD, COPD, and multiple abdominal surgeries. She was admitted to the ICU for worsening hypoxia and is now intubated due to a hypoxic event. The patient has been experiencing difficulty breathing, desaturation, and unresponsiveness. She also has leukocytosis with 18.8 WBC count, electrolyte and fluid disorder, and delirium/confusion. 

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory failure: The patient's worsening hypoxia and bilateral infiltrates on CXR suggest the possibility of respiratory failure. She is currently on ARDSnet ventilation protocol to wean FiO2 and PEEP.

2. Hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP): The patient's recent hospitalization and aspiration event increase the risk of HAP. Empiric coverage with d3 Vanc and d3 aztreonam has been started.

3. Aspiration pneumonitis: The patient's recent aspiration event may have led to aspiration pneumonitis. Flagyl has been given for aspiration pneumonia.

4. Delirium/confusion: The patient is showing signs of delirium/confusion, which can be caused by multiple factors such as sepsis, electrolyte imbalances, or medication effects.

5. Short gut syndrome: The patient's extensive workup for diarrhea has revealed the possibility of short gut syndrome. This

She was admitted to the MICU for hypoxia and is currently intubated on ARDSnet ventilation. She has a recent history of acute hypoxic events, aspiration, and delirium. The patient's allergies include latex, aspirin, colchicine, antihistamines, quinolones, vasodilators, loratadine, theophylline, opioids, cortisone, iodine, and levaquin. She has been receiving multiple medications including propofol, pantoprazole, furosemide, heparin, diltiazem, and ipratropium/albuterol.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient is currently on invasive ventilation due to acute respiratory failure. There is a risk of further deterioration in respiratory function and the need for prolonged mechanical ventilation or tracheostomy.
2. Infection: The patient has leukocytosis with 1+ GPCs in her sputum, suggesting a possible infection. Empiric antibiotic coverage has been initiated for hospital-acquired pneumonia and aspiration pneumonia.
3. Delirium: The patient has been experiencing episodes of delirium, which can be a complication of severe illness, medications, or ICU environment. Close monitoring and management of sed

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is an 80-year-old female with a history of CAD, CHF, CVA, ILD, COPD, and multiple abdominal surgeries. She was admitted to the MICU for hypoxia and is now intubated due to a hypoxic event. The patient has been experiencing difficulty breathing, desaturation, and unresponsiveness. She also has a history of diarrhea, which has not been diagnosed yet, and is currently being evaluated for possible microscopic colitis. The patient's recent events include an episode of atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response, hypotension, and resolution after receiving IV fluids. She also had an episode of shortness of breath and subsequent intubation.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's hypoxia and bilateral infiltrates on the chest X-ray suggest the possibility of acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). ARDS can lead to severe respiratory failure and may require prolonged mechanical ventilation.

2. Infection: The presence of leukocytosis and 1+ GPCs in the sputum indicates a potential respiratory infection. Given the patient's immunocompromised state and the fact that she is intubated, there is an increased risk of hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP).

3. Gastrointestinal Issues: The patient has a history of diarrhea, which has not been fully evaluated yet. Microscopic colitis is being considered, and biopsies are pending.

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 62-year-old male admitted to the ICU with multi-lumen insertion, invasive ventilation, arterial line placement, and various other medical interventions. The patient has a history of allergies to latex gloves, aspirin, colchicine, antihistamine (diphenhydramine Hcl), quinolones, vasodilators, loratadine, theophylline, opioids (morphine), cortisone, iodine, levaquin (levofloxacin), and more. The patient's last doses of antibiotics were aztreonam, vancomycin, and metronidazole. The patient is currently on propofol infusion, diltiazem, heparin sodium (prophylaxis), and pantoprazole (protonix). Review of systems is unchanged from admission except for new symptoms. The patient's vital signs show a temperature of 37.6C, heart rate of 83 bpm, blood pressure ranging from 92/44 mmHg to 129/53 mmHg, respiratory rate of 29 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 91%. The patient is on mechanical ventilation with a set tidal volume of 400 mL and respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute. The patient's ABG results indicate a pH of 7.38, PaCO2 of 46 mmHg, HCO3- of 74 mmol/L, and oxygen saturation of 148. Lab results show elevated white blood cell count of 18.8 K/uL, hemoglobin of 11.5 g/dL, platelet count of 358 K/uL, creatinine level of 0.8 mg/dL, and troponin-T level of <0.01. The patient has been diagnosed with hypoxemia, leukocytosis, electrolyte and fluid disorder, and delirium/confusion. The patient's ICU care includes nutrition, glycemic control, lines management, prophylaxis for deep vein thrombosis, stress ulcer, and ventilator-associated pneumonia. The patient's code status is full code, and the disposition is pending further evaluation.

She was intubated for hypoxemic arrest and is currently meeting criteria for ARDS. The patient also has a history of witnessed aspiration and known CHF. She is being treated in the ICU for aspiration pneumonia and complex GI issues.

The patient's vital signs show a temperature of 37.6 C (99.7 F), heart rate of 83 bpm with a range of 78-120 bpm, blood pressure of 98/48 mmHg with a range of 63-129/53 mmHg, respiratory rate of 29 breaths per minute with a range of 14-38 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 91%. The patient is on invasive ventilation, arterial line, and multi-lumen catheter.

The patient's laboratory results indicate leukocytosis with a white blood cell count of 18.8 K/uL, elevated creatinine level of 1.0 mg/dL, slightly low hemoglobin level of 11.5 g/dL, and elevated BNP level of 1100. Other lab results are within normal limits.

The patient's physical examination reveals jugular venous distention to 10cm, no liver abnormalities, crackles at the left lower lung base, and no wheezing. The patient's abdomen is soft

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 80-year-old female with a history of underlying stage IV sarcoidosis, COPD, and known CHF. She was intubated for hypoxemic arrest and is currently meeting criteria for ARDS. The patient's transfer from OSH is for a second opinion on diarrhea following colectomies for diverticulitis. The patient has multiple medical complications and conditions that require attention.

1. Respiratory: The patient is on invasive ventilation and has shown signs of acute aspiration. Further evaluation is needed, including obtaining sputum if produced, old CT scans and x-rays, and a non-contrast chest scan to consider bronchoscopic evaluation. Nebulizers should be continued.

2. Cardiovascular: A follow-up transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) is required. The patient is on Plavix, and enalapril and norvasc should be held while continuing diltiazem. A small bolus for CVP and urine output should be given.

3. Gastrointestinal: Chronic diarrhea needs to be evaluated by reviewing OSH studies regarding the workup of chronic diarrhea, rescan the abdomen, follow up biopsies from OS, and consult a GI specialist for chronic diarrhea.

4. Hematology: Elevated INR is suspected to be related to chronic diarrhea and malabsorption. Further evaluation is necessary.

5. Endocrine: Continue synthroid as per the end

4. Electrolyte Imbalance: The patient has an electrolyte and fluid disorder, which may require close monitoring and management.

Summary:
The patient is an 80-year-old female with a medical history of CAD, CHF, CVA, ILD, COPD, and multiple abdominal surgeries. She was admitted to the MICU for hypoxia and diagnosed with respiratory failure. She also has diarrhea, atrial fibrillation, electrolyte & fluid disorder, leukocytosis, and delirium/confusion. 

The patient has been intubated and placed on ventilatory support due to a hypoxic event. She required emergent intubation after experiencing aspiration and subsequent hypoxia. The patient's P/F ratio was 177, and her chest X-ray showed bilateral infiltrates, indicating the possibility of pulmonary edema or underlying ILD. She is being ventilated using the ARDSnet protocol with tidal volumes.

The patient is receiving empiric coverage for hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP) with d3 Vanc and d3 aztreonam, as well as flagyl for aspiration pneumonia. An echocardiogram was ordered today to evaluate her ejection fraction. The patient's leukocytosis is trending down, and her sputum culture showed 1+ GPCs. Further investigations, including stool culture, UCx, and sputum culture, are pending.

The patient's extensive workup for diarrhea remains inconclusive, with possible diagnoses including short gut, microscopic colitis, VIPoma, carcinoid syndrome, and fat malabsorption. Biopsies

She was admitted to the MICU for hypoxia and is now in the ICU. The patient's chief complaints are respiratory failure, diarrhea, and atrial fibrillation.

From the assessment and plan section, the following medical complications can potentially arise:

1. Hypoxia/Respiratory Failure: The patient has worsening hypoxia with central patchy infiltrates on CXR, indicating pulmonary edema or underlying ILD. 4. Delirium/Confusion: The patient is experiencing delirium or confusion, which is common in critically ill patients.

She has a witnessed aspiration and evidence of pneumonia on chest X-ray. She is currently being ventilated using ARDSnet protocol. Her condition is consistent with infection versus ARDS. The patient also presents with diarrhea, which has been extensively investigated without diagnosis. Potential leading diagnosis includes short gut syndrome, microscopic colitis, VIPoma, carcinoid syndrome, fat malabsorption, and pancreatic insufficiency. The patient's allergies include latex gloves, aspirin, colchicine, antihistamines, quinolones, vasodilators, loratadine, theophylline, opioids, cortisone, iodine, and levaquin. She is currently on various medications including antibiotics, proton pump inhibitors, ipratropium, albuterol, and flagyl.

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's current condition indicates respiratory failure due to hypoxia and the need for mechanical ventilation.
2. Infection: The presence of central patchy infiltrates on chest X-ray, elevated white blood cell count, and positive sputum culture for Staphylococcus aureus suggest a possible infection.

Summary:
The patient is an 80-year-old female with a history of stage IV sarcoidosis, COPD, and CHF. She was intubated due to respiratory failure and is currently in the ICU. The patient's condition has been complicated by aspiration pneumonia, acute CHF, and acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). She also has a history of chronic diarrhea and is undergoing evaluation for that as well. The patient's vital signs show tachycardia, hypotension, and hypoxemia. Her blood work indicates anemia and elevated white blood cell count. The patient has multiple medical complications that require ongoing management.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Aspiration pneumonia: The patient's respiratory failure and diffuse crackles on physical examination suggest aspiration pneumonia. This is a serious infection that occurs when foreign material enters the lungs through inhalation. It can lead to sepsis and respiratory failure if not treated promptly.
2. Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS): The patient's ARDS may be secondary to aspiration pneumonia or acute CHF. ARDS is a life-threatening condition characterized by severe inflammation and fluid accumulation in the lungs. It can lead to respiratory failure if not managed properly.
3. Acute Heart Failure (CHF): The patient's history of CHF and symptoms of hypoxemia, tachycardia, and hypotension suggest acute heart failure. CHF occurs when the heart cannot pump enough blood to meet the body's needs

The patient was intubated due to hypoxemia and subsequent witnessed aspiration. She is currently in the ICU and has been diagnosed with acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS).

The patient's vital signs show a temperature of 37.1C, heart rate of 106 bpm, blood pressure of 120/53 mmHg, respiratory rate of 26 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 94%. The patient's rhythm is atrial fibrillation. The central venous pressure (CVP) is 5 mmHg. The patient has received a total of 3 liters of intravenous fluids.

The patient is currently on mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume of 400 mL, respiratory rate set at 18 breaths per minute, positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) of 10 cmH2O, and fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 50%. The arterial blood gas (ABG) results indicate a pH of 7.35, partial pressure of carbon dioxide (PaCO2) of 48 mmHg, and partial pressure of oxygen (PaO2) of 190.

The patient's laboratory results show a white blood cell (WBC) count ranging from 15.5 to 18.8 thousand/mm3, hemoglobin

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:

The patient is a 64-year-old male admitted to the ICU with a chief complaint of decreased TV (tidal volume) due to ARDSnet. The patient has a history of atrial fibrillation and is currently on metoprolol for rate control. The patient also has multiple allergies, including latex gloves, aspirin, colchicine, antihistamines, quinolones, vasodilators, loratadine, theophylline, opioids, cortisone, iodine, and levofloxacin.

The patient's vital signs show a temperature of 38.1 C (100.5 F), heart rate of 106 bpm with an irregular rhythm consistent with atrial fibrillation, blood pressure ranging from 115/50 mmHg to 140/63 mmHg, respiratory rate of 30 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 98%. The patient is intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation.

The patient's fluid balance shows a net intake of 1,453 mL and output of 1,240 mL over the past 24 hours. The patient's blood products and urine output are also recorded. The patient's respiratory support includes a Vt set at 330 mL, RR set at 24 breaths per minute, PEEP at 10 cmH2O, FiO2 at 40%, and ABG results indicating a pH of 7.43, PaCO2 of 38 mmHg, and PaO2/FiO2 ratio of 290.

Laboratory results show leukocytosis with a WBC count of 20.0 K/uL, hyponatremia with a sodium level of 103 mEq/L, hyperkalemia with a potassium level of 5.6 mEq/L, and elevated lactate levels at 9.0 mmol/L. Other lab values are within normal limits.

Assessment and plan include alterations in nutrition, atrial fibrillation, hypotension, hypoxemia, leukocytosis, electrolyte and fluid disorder, delirium/confusion, and ICU care. The patient is receiving nutrition through a feeding tube, and lines have been placed for arterial blood gas monitoring and medication administration. Prophylactic measures are in place for deep vein thrombosis, stress ulcers, and ventilator-associated pneumonia.

Potential Medical Complications:

Based on the provided information, potential medical complications for this patient may include:

1. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): The patient is receiving mechanical ventilation, which increases the risk of developing pneumonia. Close monitoring for signs of infection and appropriate antibiotic therapy would be necessary.

2. Delirium/confusion: The patient is experiencing delirium or confusion, as indicated in the assessment and plan section. This could be due to the underlying illness, medications, or other factors. It is important to address this issue promptly to prevent further complications.

3. Electrolyte and fluid disorder: The patient's labs indicate hyponatremia and hyperkalemia. These electrolyte imbalances can lead to various complications such as cardiac arrhythmias, muscle weakness, and renal dysfunction. Close monitoring and appropriate management of fluid and electrolyte balance are crucial.

4. Atrial fibrillation: The patient has a history of atrial fibrillation, and it is currently present. This condition increases the risk of clot formation and potential embolic events. Anticoagulation therapy may be necessary to prevent thromboembolic complications.

5. Leukocytosis: The patient's white blood cell count is elevated, suggesting an inflammatory response or infection. Monitoring for signs of infection and appropriate antibiotic therapy would be necessary to prevent the progression of infection.

6. Hypotension: The patient's blood pressure is consistently low, indicating hypotension. This can lead to inadequate tissue perfusion and organ dysfunction. Close monitoring and appropriate hemodynamic support are required.

Please note that this summary and potential complications are based solely on the provided progress

She was previously receiving vancomycin, metronidazole, and aztreonam but these medications were stopped as per the plan. She is currently on propofol infusion, metoprolol, heparin sodium (prophylaxis), and other medications.

Her vital signs include a temperature of 38.1C (100.5F), heart rate of 106 bpm, blood pressure of 115/50 mmHg, respiratory rate of 30 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 98%. She is in atrial fibrillation.

Her lab results show elevated white blood cell count, slightly low hemoglobin level, normal platelet count, and abnormal kidney and liver function tests. Her electrolyte levels are within normal range.

Microbiology cultures reveal positive MRSA in sputum, negative urine and stool cultures,

Summary:
The patient is an 80-year-old female with a medical history of CAD, CHF, CVA, ILD, COPD, and multiple abdominal surgeries. She was admitted for worsening hypoxia and central patchy infiltrates on CXR, which could represent pulmonary edema or underlying ILD. She had a witnessed aspiration and then experienced a hypoxic event, resulting in emergent intubation due to unresponsiveness. She was ventilated with ARDSnet protocol and has been in the MICU for hypoxia.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's hypoxia and bilateral infiltrates on CXR indicate the possibility of ARDS (acute respiratory distress syndrome), which can lead to severe respiratory failure.
2. Sepsis: The patient has leukocytosis, negative urine analysis, but positive sputum culture for MRSA. Blood cultures are pending, but she is already receiving antibiotics empirically.
3. Gastrointestinal Issues: The patient has diarrhea, for which extensive workup has been done without diagnosis. Possible causes include short gut syndrome, infections, microscopic colitis, VIPoma, carcinoid syndrome, fat malabsorption, and pancreatic insufficiency. Biopsies are pending, and further tests are needed to determine the underlying cause.
4. Cardiac Arrhythmia: The patient has atrial fibrillation and is currently being treated with diltiazem. She is also at risk for

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 80-year-old female with a history of CAD, CHF, CVA, ILD, COPD, and multiple abdominal surgeries. She was admitted for worsening hypoxia and central patchy infiltrates on the chest X-ray. She had a witnessed aspiration and then experienced a hypoxic event, resulting in emergent intubation. The patient is currently in the MICU for hypoxia and has been ventilated using the ARDSnet protocol. She has a preserved EF on echo and CT chest consistent with infection vs. ARDS.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Hypoxia: The patient's primary issue is hypoxia, which has led to respiratory failure. She requires continuous monitoring of oxygen levels and appropriate ventilation support.
2. Infection: The patient has positive MRSA screens in her sputum on [4-12] and [4-13], indicating a possible MRSA infection. She is currently being treated with vancomycin and aztreonam for empirical coverage of healthcare-associated pneumonia (HAP). Further cultures and sensitivity testing are pending.
3. Sepsis: The patient had new leukocytosis yesterday but is now trending down. Her urine analysis/culture is negative, and she is on flagyl for aspiration pneumonia. Blood cultures are pending, and she may have already received antibiotics, which could affect the results.
4. Diarrhea: The patient has had extensive workup without a diagnosis

   Assessment/Plan:  80 F with CAD, CHF, CVA, ILD, COPD and multiple

   was admitted to MICU for hypoxia.  Continues to require intubation.
   # Hypoxia Resp Failure: Unable to be extubated and did not tolerate PS
   trial yesterday although oxygen requirements decreasing.  Picture most
   consistent w/ PNA (? Aspiration PNA).  Patient was admitted with
   worsening hypoxia and CXR with central patchy infiltrates that could
   represent pulmonary edema vs underlying ILD. Patient has hx ILD but is
   not on home O2. Had a witnessed aspiration and then had a hypoxic event
   where she acutely desated and became unresponsive requiring emergent
   intubation. P/F ratio 177 and CXR with bilateral infiltrates and she
   was ventilated with ardsnet protocol.  Echo with preserved EF.  CT
   chest consistent with infection vs. ARDS.   Bronchoscopy ([**4-15**])
   appeared normal with BAL sent.
   - Ventilator: Overbreathing vent with consequent respiratory alkalosis
   - Decrease PEEP to 5
   - Trial of PSV in afternoon w/ hope for extubation today
   - Continue Vanc (Day 1 = [**4-11**]) for MRSA in BAL fluid d6 out of 8 today,
   will increase to 1g q12
   - Stop aztreonam (D1 = [**4-12**])
   - Continue ipratropium q 6 and albuterol q 4hrs PRN
   - Lasix 20 mg IV w/ goal 1 L negative as still + for LOS
   # Sepsis: Now normotensive and off pressors for several days.  ? from
   pulmonary source.  UA/cx negative.  Sputum with MRSA.  Legionella
   antigen negative.  Stool culture (one c.diff included) negative.
   - Treating PNA as above, reculture if febrile
   .
   # History COPD and question of ILD: Not on home O2.
   - Holding Advair and Singulair while intubated
   - continue nebs, flovent while intubated
   - Otherwise treatment as above
   # Diarrhea:   Has had extensive w/u without diagnosis. Leading
   diagnosis is short gut ("short colon") although short colon does not
   typically cause diarrhea. Infections have been repeated r/o.
   Microscopic colitis is under consideration and biopsies are pending at
   OSH. Gastrin elevated, 5HIAA minimally elevated from OSH; VIP from OSH
   pending. Pancreatic insufficiency should also be considered.  Once TF
   were restarted ([**Date range (1) 625**]) diarrhea worsened.

   normal limits.
   - Continue nortriptyline

   - OSH colon biopsy, VIP pending
   - GI consulted; will see patient once extubated
   # Anemia: Unclear etiology.  Hct stable.  Iron studies c/w mild
   iron-deficiency.  Not guaiac positive.
   - trend for now
   # Gastritis/ GERD:
   - Continue PPI IV, avoid PO PPI
   # CAD: Not on ASA? Will discuss with patient once extubated.
   - Continue plavix
   -  Holding simvastatin

Summary:
The patient is an 80-year-old female with multiple comorbidities, including coronary artery disease (CAD), congestive heart failure (CHF), cerebrovascular accident (CVA), interstitial lung disease (ILD), chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), and multiple abdominal surgeries. She was admitted to the ICU for hypoxia and required intubation. The patient has been diagnosed with pneumonia (PNA) and is being treated with vancomycin for MRSA in the BAL fluid. She also has sepsis, possibly from a pulmonary source, and is being treated accordingly. The patient's diarrhea remains undiagnosed despite extensive workup, including ruling out infections and considering microscopic colitis, pancreatic insufficiency, and short colon. She is currently on total parenteral nutrition (TPN) and receiving medications for her other medical conditions.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient is unable to be extubated and did not tolerate a spontaneous breathing trial yesterday. This indicates a risk of continued respiratory failure and the need for ongoing mechanical ventilation.
2. Sepsis: The patient has sepsis, likely of pulmonary origin, which needs to be closely monitored and treated aggressively to prevent further complications.
3. Diarrhea: The patient's diarrhea remains unexplained despite extensive workup. Further investigations are needed to determine the underlying cause and guide appropriate treatment.

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:

The patient presents with shortness of breath (SOB) and diarrhea. The stool culture has confirmed Clostridium difficile (C-diff) infection. The patient is currently receiving vancomycin and aztreonam, with a plan to obtain a bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) to guide further antibiotic therapy. Lasix has been initiated to manage fluid overload. The patient's PEEP has been decreased to 8, and ABG results show a pH of 7.47, indicating respiratory alkalosis. The patient's respiratory rate has been reduced to 18 breaths per minute. The patient underwent a pressure support trial but experienced significant overbreathing, so they were placed back on assist-control ventilation (AC).

The patient has multiple known allergies, including latex, aspirin, colchicine, antihistamines, quinolones, vasodilators, loratadine, theophylline, opioids, cortisone, iodine, and levaquin. The last doses of antibiotics administered were metronidazole on [**2172-4-15**] at 08:00 AM, vancomycin on [**2172-4-16**] at 12:00 AM, and aztreonam on [**2172-4-16**] at 04:00 AM.

The patient is receiving propofol at a rate of 15 mcg/kg

Summary:
The patient is an 80-year-old female with multiple comorbidities including coronary artery disease (CAD), congestive heart failure (CHF), cerebrovascular accident (CVA), interstitial lung disease (ILD), chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), and multiple abdominal surgeries. The patient was admitted for worsening hypoxia and chest X-ray findings suggestive of pulmonary edema or underlying ILD. She experienced a witnessed aspiration and subsequently had a hypoxic event requiring emergent intubation. The patient is currently in the MICU for hypoxia and respiratory failure.

The patient's recent medical history includes an episode of sepsis, which is trending down. She also has a history of COPD and possible ILD, although she is not on home oxygen. Other conditions include gastritis/GERD, atrial fibrillation (afib), hypothyroidism, and diarrhea of unknown etiology. The patient has undergone extensive workup for the diarrhea, including stool cultures, microscopic colitis biopsy, gastrin levels, 5HIAA levels, VIP levels, and TTG levels. The stool osm gap suggests a secretory diarrhea. The patient's current medications include vancomycin, pantoprazole, furosemide, heparin sodium, and propofol.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.6C, heart rate of 97 bpm, blood pressure of 118/51 mm

Summary:
The patient is an 80-year-old female with multiple medical conditions including coronary artery disease (CAD), congestive heart failure (CHF), cerebrovascular accident (CVA), interstitial lung disease (ILD), chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), and multiple abdominal surgeries. She was admitted to the medical intensive care unit (MICU) for hypoxia and later intubated due to a hypoxic event. The patient has been diagnosed with pneumonia and sepsis, and is being treated with antibiotics for MRSA in her sputum. Other ongoing assessments and plans include respiratory failure, diarrhea, gastritis/GERD, CAD, atrial fibrillation (afib), and hypothyroidism.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure is currently being managed with mechanical ventilation. However, there is a potential risk of further deterioration in lung function, leading to persistent or worsening respiratory failure.
2. Diarrhea: Despite extensive workup, the cause of the patient's diarrhea remains undiagnosed. There is a risk of continued fluid and electrolyte imbalance, dehydration, and malnutrition if the diarrhea persists.
3. Infections: The patient has already had multiple infections, including pneumonia and sepsis. There is a risk of developing new infections due to her immunocompromised state and prolonged hospital stay.
4. Cardiac Conditions: The patient has a history of CAD and CHF, and

Summary:
Summary of the patient's health progress in the ICU:
The patient is an 80-year-old female with a history of stage IV sarcoidosis, COPD, and known CHF. She was intubated due to respiratory failure caused by aspiration pneumonia and is currently meeting criteria for ARDS. The patient also has complex GI issues, which were the original reason for transfer from OSH.

Potential medical complications that can arise:
1. Aspiration pneumonia: The patient's history of COPD and CHF puts her at risk for recurrent aspiration, which can lead to pneumonia. The current respiratory failure is suspected to be caused by aspiration pneumonia.
2. Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS): The patient is meeting criteria for ARDS, a life-threatening condition characterized by severe inflammation and fluid accumulation in the lungs, leading to decreased oxygenation and respiratory distress.
3. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): Due to the patient's prolonged intubation, there is an increased risk of developing VAP, which is a type of lung infection acquired during mechanical ventilation.
4. Chronic diarrhea: The patient has a history of chronic diarrhea, and further evaluation is needed to determine the underlying cause.
5. Iron deficiency anemia: The patient has mild iron deficiency anemia, which may contribute to fatigue and weakness.
6. Mixed anemia: The patient also has mixed anemia, which may be due to chronic disease or another underlying cause.
7. Hyperglycemia: The patient's blood glucose levels have been elevated on several occasions, indicating potential difficulty in maintaining glycemic control.
8. Fluid overload: The patient's fluid balance shows positive values, indicating fluid overload, which can lead to pulmonary edema and worsen respiratory function.
9. Thromboembolic events: As an immobilized patient, there is an increased risk of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and pulmonary embolism (PE).

Please note that these potential complications are based on the information provided in the progress note, and a comprehensive evaluation by healthcare professionals is necessary for accurate diagnosis and management.

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:

The patient is an 80-year-old female with a history of underlying stage IV sarcoidosis, COPD, and known CHF. She presented with hypoxemia and witnessed aspiration. The patient is currently intubated and meeting criteria for ARDS. She was transferred from OSH for a second opinion on diarrhea, which is a complication from past colectomies for diverticulitis.

The patient's vital signs show a temperature of 37.7C (99.8F), heart rate of 97 bpm, blood pressure ranging from 118/51 to 147/63 mmHg, respiratory rate of 34 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 98%. She has a CVP of 4 mmHg and is receiving fluids, with a total input of 1,755 mL and output of 1,055 mL. Her urine output is 1,045 mL, and she has had some NG output. 

The patient's respiratory support includes being on a ventilator with a set Vt of 330 mL, RR of 18 breaths per minute, PEEP of 8 cmH2O, FiO2 of 40%, and an RSBI of 147. Her ABG results indicate a pH of 7.48, PaCO2 of 32 mmHg, PaO2/FiO2 ratio of 290, and Ve of 11.7 L/min. Physical examination reveals that the patient is intubated, sedated, and responds appropriately. She has a CTA anteriorly and edema in her extremities. 

Laboratory results show a WBC count ranging from 14.4 to 17.3 thousand/mm3, Hct of 29.3-32.0%, Plt of 287-376 thousand/mm3, Cr of 0.5-0.9 mg/dL, TCO2 of 22-28 mmol/L, and Glucose of 95-174 mg/dL. Other lab values include a PT/PTT/INR of 14.9/36.0/1.3, CK/CKMB/Troponin-T of 40/<0.01/<0.01, ALT/AST of 9-23 U/L, Alk Phos/T Bili of 81/1.1, and LDH of 331 IU/L. Stool lytes gap is 66, and Micro-BAL grew MRSA. 

Assessment and Plan:
The patient's respiratory failure is likely due to aspiration pneumonia, and she also has complex GI issues that require evaluation. The plan includes increasing vancomycin to [**Hospital1 **], discontinuing aztreonam, obtaining old CT scans and x-rays for review, weaning vent by decreasing PEEP and diuresis, transitioning to Precide

   unresponsive requiring emergent intubation. P/F ratio 177 and CXR with
   bilateral infiltrates and she was ventilated with ardsnet protocol.
   Echo with preserved EF.  CT chest consistent with infection vs. ARDS.

   Microscopic colitis is under consideration and biopsies are pending at

Summary:
The patient is a 64-year-old male with a chief complaint of respiratory failure. The patient has a history of multiple comorbidities including CAD, CHF, CVA, ILD, COPD, and abdominal surgeries. He was admitted to the MICU for hypoxia and requires intubation due to aspiration pneumonia. The patient's condition has been complicated by sepsis, hypotension, diarrhea, anemia, gastritis/GERD, atrial fibrillation, and hypothyroidism.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory status remains critical, requiring mechanical ventilation. There is a risk of further deterioration and the need for prolonged intubation or tracheostomy.
2. Sepsis: The patient has shown signs of sepsis, possibly due to a pulmonary source. Close monitoring for fever, hypotension, and signs of organ dysfunction is necessary. Broad-spectrum antibiotics are being administered to cover potential pathogens, including MRSA.
3. Hypotension: The patient experienced hypotension likely due to the use of precedex and fentanyl. Blood pressure should be closely monitored, and vasopressor support may be required.
4. Diarrhea: The patient has been experiencing diarrhea despite extensive workup. The cause remains undiagnosed, with possibilities including microscopic colitis, pancreatic insufficiency, or short gut syndrome. Nutritional support and further investigation are needed.

   Assessment and Plan
   Assessment/Plan:  80 F with CAD, CHF, CVA, ILD, COPD and multiple
   abdominal surgeries tranfer from OSH for 2nd opinion of diarrhea who
   was admitted to MICU for hypoxia.  Continues to require intubation.
   # Hypoxia Resp Failure: Unable to be extubated and did not tolerate PS
   trial yesterday although oxygen requirements decreasing.  Picture most
   consistent w/ PNA (? Aspiration PNA).  Patient was admitted with
   worsening hypoxia and CXR with central patchy infiltrates that could
   represent pulmonary edema vs underlying ILD. Patient has hx ILD but is
   not on home O2. Had a witnessed aspiration and then had a hypoxic event
   where she acutely desated and became unresponsive requiring emergent
   intubation. P/F ratio 177 and CXR with bilateral infiltrates and she
   was ventilated with ardsnet protocol.  Echo with preserved EF.  CT
   chest consistent with infection vs. ARDS.   Bronchoscopy ([**4-15**])
   appeared normal with BAL sent.
   - Ventilator: Overbreathing vent with consequent respiratory alkalosis
   - Decrease PEEP to 5
   - Trial of PSV in afternoon w/ hope for extubation today
   - Continue Vanc (Day 1 = [**4-11**]) for MRSA in BAL fluid d6 out of 8 today,
   will increase to 1g q12
   - Stop aztreonam (D1 = [**4-12**])
   - Continue ipratropium q 6 and albuterol q 4hrs PRN
   - Lasix 20 mg IV w/ goal 1 L negative as still + for LOS
   # Sepsis: Now normotensive and off pressors for several days.  ? from
   pulmonary source.  UA/cx negative.  Sputum with MRSA.  Legionella
   antigen negative.  Stool culture (one c.diff included) negative.
   - Treating PNA as above, reculture if febrile
   .
   # History COPD and question of ILD: Not on home O2.
   - Holding Advair and Singulair while intubated
   - continue nebs, flovent while intubated
   - Otherwise treatment as above
   # Diarrhea:   Has had extensive w/u without diagnosis. Leading
   diagnosis is short gut ("short colon") although short colon does not
   typically cause diarrhea. Infections have been repeated r/o.
   Microscopic colitis is under consideration and biopsies are pending at
   OSH. Gastrin elevated, 5HIAA minimally elevated from OSH; VIP from OSH
   pending. Pancreatic insufficiency should also be considered.  Once TF
   were restarted ([**Date range (1) 625**]) diarrhea worsened.
   Stool Osm gap 66, more suggestive of a secretory diarrhea. TTG within
   normal limits.
   - Continue nortriptyline
   - Holding immodium
   - Repeat c.diff ([**4-15**])
   - OSH colon biopsy, VIP pending
   - GI consulted; will see patient once extubated
   # Anemia: Unclear etiology.  Hct stable.  Iron studies c/w mild
   iron-deficiency.  Not guaiac positive.
   - trend for now
   # Gastritis/ GERD:
   - Continue PPI IV, avoid PO PPI
   # CAD: Not on ASA? Will discuss with patient once extubated.
   - Continue plavix
   -  Holding simvastatin
   # Afib:  In and out of afib.  Rate now better controlled on metoprolol.
   - Continue diltiazem
   - Continue metoprolol (added [**4-14**])
   - Should be on coumadin for anticoagulation but will hold until GI
   decides about scope and until d/c from ICU
   # Hypothyroidism: TSH was 3.71 at OSH and Levothyroxine dose appears to
   have been decreased from 200mg to 100mg daily.

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is an 80-year-old woman with a history of CAD, CHF, CVA, ILD, COPD, and multiple abdominal surgeries. She was admitted to the MICU for hypoxia and is currently intubated. The patient's main concerns include hypoxia, respiratory failure, sepsis, diarrhea, anemia, gastritis/GERD, CAD, atrial fibrillation, and hypothyroidism.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Hypoxia: The patient's low oxygen saturation levels indicate a potential complication of respiratory failure or pneumonia.
2. Respiratory Failure: The patient's inability to be extubated and tolerate a pressure support trial suggests ongoing respiratory failure.
3. Sepsis: The patient's normotensive state and negative urine analysis make a pulmonary source of sepsis likely. Treatment for MRSA should be continued, and reculture if febrile.
4. Diarrhea: Despite extensive workup, the cause of the patient's diarrhea remains undiagnosed. Short gut syndrome, infections, microscopic colitis, pancreatic insufficiency, and other causes should be considered.
5. Anemia: The unclear etiology of anemia warrants further investigation. Iron studies indicate mild iron deficiency, and not guaiac positive.
6. Gastritis/GERD: The patient's gastritis/GERD should be managed with continued PPI IV and avoiding PO PPI.
7. CAD

   Assessment and Plan
   Assessment/Plan:  80 F with CAD, CHF, CVA, ILD, COPD and multiple
   abdominal surgeries tranfer from OSH for 2nd opinion of diarrhea who
   was admitted to MICU for hypoxia.  Continues to require intubation.
   # Hypoxia Resp Failure: Unable to be extubated and did not tolerate PS
   trial yesterday although oxygen requirements decreasing.  Picture most
   consistent w/ PNA (? Aspiration PNA).  Patient was admitted with
   worsening hypoxia and CXR with central patchy infiltrates that could
   represent pulmonary edema vs underlying ILD. Patient has hx ILD but is
   not on home O2. Had a witnessed aspiration and then had a hypoxic event
   where she acutely desated and became unresponsive requiring emergent
   intubation. P/F ratio 177 and CXR with bilateral infiltrates and she
   was ventilated with ardsnet protocol.  Echo with preserved EF.  CT
   chest consistent with infection vs. ARDS.   Bronchoscopy ([**4-15**])
   appeared normal with BAL sent.
   - Ventilator: Overbreathing vent with consequent respiratory alkalosis
   - Decrease PEEP to 5
   - Trial of PSV in afternoon w/ hope for extubation today
   - Continue Vanc (Day 1 = [**4-11**]) for MRSA in BAL fluid d6 out of 8 today,
   will increase to 1g q12
   - Stop aztreonam (D1 = [**4-12**])
   - Continue ipratropium q 6 and albuterol q 4hrs PRN
   - Lasix 20 mg IV w/ goal 1 L negative as still + for LOS
   # Sepsis: Now normotensive and off pressors for several days.  ? from
   pulmonary source.  UA/cx negative.  Sputum with MRSA.  Legionella
   antigen negative.  Stool culture (one c.diff included) negative.
   - Treating PNA as above, reculture if febrile
   .
   # History COPD and question of ILD: Not on home O2.
   - Holding Advair and Singulair while intubated
   - continue nebs, flovent while intubated
   - Otherwise treatment as above
   # Diarrhea:   Has had extensive w/u without diagnosis. Leading
   diagnosis is short gut ("short colon") although short colon does not
   typically cause diarrhea. Infections have been repeated r/o.
   Microscopic colitis is under consideration and biopsies are pending at
   OSH. Gastrin elevated, 5HIAA minimally elevated from OSH; VIP from OSH
   pending. Pancreatic insufficiency should also be considered.  Once TF
   were restarted ([**Date range (1) 625**]) diarrhea worsened.
   Stool Osm gap 66, more suggestive of a secretory diarrhea. TTG within
   normal limits.
   - Continue nortriptyline
   - Holding immodium
   - Repeat c.diff ([**4-15**])
   - OSH colon biopsy, VIP pending
   - GI consulted; will see patient once extubated
   # Anemia: Unclear etiology.  Hct stable.  Iron studies c/w mild
   iron-deficiency.  Not guaiac positive.
   - trend for now
   # Gastritis/ GERD:
   - Continue PPI IV, avoid PO PPI
   # CAD: Not on ASA? Will discuss with patient once extubated.
   - Continue plavix
   -  Holding simvastatin
   # Afib:  In and out of afib.  Rate now better controlled on metoprolol.
   - Continue diltiazem
   - Continue metoprolol (added [**4-14**])
   - Should be on coumadin for anticoagulation but will hold until GI
   decides about scope and until d/c from ICU
   # Hypothyroidism: TSH was 3.71 at OSH and Levothyroxine dose appears to
   have been decreased from 200mg to 100mg daily.
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Vivonex (Full) - [**2172-4-16**] 02:14 PM 50 mL/hour
   Glycemic Control:  Blood sugar well controlled

   Arterial Line - [**2172-4-12**] 02:35 PM

   Stress ulcer: PPI
   VAP: HOB elevation, Mouth care, Daily wake up, RSBI

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is an 80-year-old female with a history of CAD, CHF, CVA, ILD, COPD, and multiple abdominal surgeries. She was admitted to the MICU for hypoxia and required intubation. She has been diagnosed with pneumonia (PNA) and sepsis, possibly due to a pulmonary source. The patient also has chronic diarrhea of unknown etiology and anemia of unclear origin. She has a history of gastritis/GERD, CAD, atrial fibrillation, and hypothyroidism.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's worsening hypoxia and central patchy infiltrates on chest X-ray indicate the possibility of respiratory failure due to pneumonia or pulmonary edema. She is currently on mechanical ventilation with a ventilator overbreathing, leading to respiratory alkalosis. Decreasing PEEP to 5 and considering a trial of pressure support ventilation (PSV) have been planned.
2. Sepsis: The patient's previous normotension and off pressors indicate a potential resolution of septic shock. However, she remains at risk for recurrent sepsis due to her underlying PNA and positive sputum culture for MRSA. Continuing appropriate antibiotic therapy is essential.
3. Diarrhea: The patient's extensive workup has not identified a specific cause for her chronic diarrhea. Microscopic colitis, pancreatic insufficiency, and other gastrointestinal disorders should be considered.

Summary:
The patient is an 80-year-old female with a history of stage IV sarcoidosis, COPD, and chronic heart failure. She was intubated due to respiratory failure and is currently in the ICU. The patient has been experiencing diarrhea, which is believed to be related to past colectomies for diverticulitis. She also has a known allergy to latex, aspirin, colchicine, antihistamines, quinolones, vasodilators, loratadine, theophylline, opioids, cortisone, iodine, levaquin, and more.

The patient's vital signs include a temperature of 37.8C (100.1F), a heart rate of 94 bpm, blood pressure ranging from 112/44 mmHg to 141/73 mmHg, respiratory rate of 33 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 93%. She is on mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume of 330 mL, respiratory rate set at 18 breaths per minute, PEEP of 5 cmH2O, FiO2 of 40%, and an RSBI of 115. Her blood gases show pH of 7.45, PaCO2 of 41 mmHg, PaO2/FiO2 ratio of 203, and oxygen consumption of 13.9 L/min.

Physical examination reveals that the patient is intubated and sedated,

The patient has multiple allergies, including latex, aspirin, colchicine, antihistamines, quinolones, vasodilators, loratadine, theophylline, opioids, cortisone, iodine, and levaquin. She is on mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume of 330 mL, respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute, positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) of 5 cmH

   Assessment/Plan:  80 F with CAD, CHF, CVA, ILD, COPD and multiple
   abdominal surgeries tranfer from OSH for 2nd opinion of diarrhea who
   was admitted to MICU for hypoxia.  Continues to require intubation.
   # Hypoxia Resp Failure:
   Picture most consistent w/ PNA (? Aspiration PNA).  Not able to wean on
   vent, still tachypneic with abundant secretions. Sputum has grown MRSA.
   [**Month (only) 51**] have had subtherapeutic levels on vancomycin limiting resolution of
   the MRSA infection.
   Patient was admitted with worsening hypoxia and CXR with central patchy
   infiltrates that could represent pulmonary edema vs underlying ILD.
   Patient has hx ILD but is not on home O2. Had a witnessed aspiration
   and then had a hypoxic event where she acutely desated and became
   unresponsive requiring emergent intubation. P/F ratio 177 and CXR with
   bilateral infiltrates and she was ventilated with ardsnet protocol.
   Echo with preserved EF.  CT chest consistent with infection vs. ARDS.
   Bronchoscopy ([**4-15**]) appeared normal with BAL sent.
   - Ventilator: Overbreathing vent with consequent respiratory alkalosis
   - Increase PEEP back to 10 today
   - Continue Vanc (Day 1 = [**4-11**]) for MRSA in BAL fluid, check vanco trough
   this AM
   - Repeat sputum today, broaden if increasing fever curve or evidence of
   other pathogens from sputum
   - Continue ipratropium q 6 and albuterol q 4hrs PRN
   - Diurese as BP tolerates, try for 1L negative
   - Obtain films from OSH to get a better sense of preexisting pulmonary
   disease
   # Hypotension
   Likely due to precedex, Fentanyl yesterday. Follow BP today. Will
   change to propofol today.
   # Sepsis: Now normotensive and off pressors for several days.  ? from
   pulmonary source.  UA/cx negative.  Sputum with MRSA.  Legionella
   antigen negative.  Stool culture (one c.diff included) negative.
   - Treating PNA as above, reculture if febrile
   .
   # History COPD and question of ILD: Not on home O2.
   - Holding Advair and Singulair while intubated
   - continue nebs, flovent while intubated
   - Otherwise treatment as above
   # Diarrhea:   Has had extensive w/u without diagnosis. Leading
   diagnosis is short gut ("short colon") although short colon does not
   typically cause diarrhea. Infections have been repeated r/o.
   Microscopic colitis is under consideration and biopsies are pending at
   OSH. Gastrin elevated, 5HIAA minimally elevated from OSH; VIP from OSH
   pending. Pancreatic insufficiency should also be considered.  Once TF
   were restarted ([**Date range (1) 625**]) diarrhea worsened.
   Stool Osm gap 66, more suggestive of a secretory diarrhea. TTG within
   normal limits.
   - Continue nortriptyline
   - Holding immodium
   - Repeat c.diff ([**4-15**])
   - OSH colon biopsy, VIP pending
   - GI consulted; will see patient once extubated
   # Anemia: Unclear etiology.  Hct stable.  Iron studies c/w mild
   iron-deficiency.  Not guaiac positive.
   - trend for now
   # Gastritis/ GERD:
   - Continue PPI IV
   # CAD: Not on ASA? Will discuss with patient once extubated.
   - Continue plavix
   -  Holding simvastatin
   # Afib:  In and out of afib.  Rate now better controlled on metoprolol.
   - Continue diltiazem
   - Continue metoprolol (added [**4-14**])
   - Should be on coumadin for anticoagulation but will hold until GI
   decides about scope and until d/c from ICU
   # Hypothyroidism: TSH was 3.71 at OSH and Levothyroxine dose appears to
   have been decreased from 200mg to 100mg daily.
   ICU Care
   Nutrition: With diarrhea ?how much absorbing feeds. Check albumin,
   consider TPN if lower/stable and stop TFs.

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 80-year-old female with a medical history of CAD, CHF, CVA, ILD, COPD, and multiple abdominal surgeries. She was admitted to the ICU for hypoxia and is currently intubated due to ARDS. She has been diagnosed with MRSA pneumonia and has subtherapeutic levels of vancomycin, which is limiting the resolution of the infection. Her respiratory support includes being on a ventilator with CMV/ASSIST/AutoFlow mode, set Vt of 330 mL, RR of 18, PEEP of 10 cmH2O, FiO2 of 50%, PIP of 30 cmH2O, and plateau pressure of 30 cmH2O.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Hypoxia: The patient's primary concern is her worsening hypoxia, leading to ARDS. It is crucial to maintain adequate oxygenation and continue treatment for MRSA pneumonia.
2. Ventilator-Associated Pneumonia (VAP): Due to the prolonged intubation, there is a risk of developing VAP. The patient's current management includes elevating the head of the bed, performing mouth care, and implementing daily wake-up trials to assess readiness to extubate.
3. Sepsis: The patient may be at risk for sepsis due to the MRSA infection and other potential sources of infection. Close monitoring of vital signs and appropriate antibiotic

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is admitted to the ICU with a chief complaint of ARDS (Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome). The patient has been receiving mechanical ventilation and has been on precedex for sedation, but it was switched to propofol due to difficulty extubating. The patient's allergies, medications, and infusions are documented.

The patient's vital signs show a temperature of 37.8 C (100.1 F), heart rate of 111 bpm with atrial fibrillation, blood pressure ranging from 123/55 mmHg to 135/57 mmHg, respiratory rate of 33 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 100%. The patient is on a ventilator in CMV/ASSIST/AutoFlow mode with a set tidal volume of 330 mL, respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute, PEEP of 10 cmH2O, FiO2 of 50%, and plateau pressure of 30 cmH2O. The ABG results indicate a pH of 7.50, PaCO2 of 36 mmHg, PaO2/FiO2 ratio of 330, and oxygen consumption of 11.3 L/min.

The patient's lab results show leukocytosis with a white blood cell count of 14.4 K/uL, slightly low hemoglobin level of 9.4 g/dL, elevated glucose level of 174 mg/dL, normal sodium level of 137 mEq/L, slightly low potassium level of 3.5 mEq/L, low albumin level of 2.2 g/dL, and elevated lactate level of 1.3 mmol/L.

The patient's physical examination is incomplete due to intubation, but there are no signs of peripheral vascular abnormalities, skin abnormalities, or neurologic abnormalities.

The patient's assessment and plan include alterations in nutrition, atrial fibrillation, hypotension, hypoxemia, leukocytosis, electrolyte and fluid disorder, and delirium/confusion. The patient is receiving nutritional support through Vivonex at a rate of 50 mL/hour and has multiple lines including an arterial line and a PICC line.

Potential medical complications that can arise include ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), stress ulcer, deep vein thrombosis (DVT), and electrolyte imbalances. It is important to monitor the patient closely for any signs of worsening hypoxemia, infection, or fluid imbalance.

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 80-year-old female with a history of CAD, CHF, CVA, ILD, COPD, and multiple abdominal surgeries. She was admitted to the MICU for hypoxia and later transferred to the ICU for further management. The patient requires intubation and mechanical ventilation due to severe respiratory failure. She has been diagnosed with pneumonia, likely aspiration pneumonia (PNA), and is infected with MRSA. The patient also has sepsis of unknown origin, hypotension, anemia, gastritis/GERD, atrial fibrillation, and hypothyroidism.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): Due to the patient's prolonged mechanical ventilation, there is a risk of developing VAP. Measures such as elevating the head of bed, performing regular mouth care, and ensuring daily wake-up calls will be taken to reduce this risk.
2. Deep vein thrombosis (DVT): Immobility and the use of central venous catheters increase the risk of DVT. Prophylactic measures, such as the use of subcutaneous unfractionated heparin and compression stockings, will be implemented to prevent DVT.
3. Stress ulcers: The patient is at an increased risk of developing stress ulcers due to critical illness and mechanical ventilation. Prophylactic therapy with proton pump inhibitors will be continued to prevent stress ulcers.
4. Catheter-related bloodstream infections

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is an 80-year-old female with a history of CAD, CHF, CVA, ILD, COPD, and multiple abdominal surgeries. She was admitted to the ICU for hypoxia and is currently intubated. The patient has been diagnosed with pneumonia (PNA) caused by MRSA, and there is a question of aspiration PNA. She also has hypotension, sepsis (now resolved), COPD with potential ILD, and diarrhea of unknown etiology. The patient's current medications include propofol, metoprolol, heparin sodium, and PPI IV.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:
1. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP)
2. Deep vein thrombosis (DVT)
3. Stress ulcers
4. Nosocomial infection due to prolonged ICU stay
5. Complications related to the underlying comorbidities such as CAD, CHF, CVA, ILD, COPD
6. Further deterioration of the respiratory status leading to respiratory failure
7. Development of new infections due to immunosuppression and invasive procedures
8. Malnutrition and poor nutritional status due to prolonged tube feeding and diarrhea
9. Possible gastrointestinal bleeding due to stress ulcers or other gastrointestinal issues
10. Arrhythmias, particularly atrial fibrillation, which is already present.

Please note that these potential complications are based on the information provided in the progress note.
